instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with buzzing sound
threads.message: This <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board had liquid damage, mostly in the area of the USB-C circuitry. I replaced some corroded resistors and the machine starts up and functions normally. Except that any time an audio signal is produced, the left speaker buzzes audibly for a few seconds, then goes quiet. Startup chime, system alert sound, any audio will produce the temporary buzz. Any pointers as to where I should look?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with buzzing sound
threads.message:
Audio amplifiers are near the USB-C area.
There must be corrosion.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with buzzing sound
threads.message: Yup, you're right. Upon closer inspection, the liquid damage extended to left speaker amplifiers. I see some potentially corroded capacitors and inductances. Any tips on troubleshooting an audio circuit?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with buzzing sound
threads.message:
I use JBC NASE-2 to work in such area.
You also need to resolder the chip, or change it.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with buzzing sound
threads.message: I removed the corroded <CHIP>U6420</CHIP> and the buzzing is gone. Since this audio amplifier seems extremely hard to find, I decided to leave it as it is. Since there are 2 speakers on each side, I can barely hear the difference with one of the four nonfunctional.
